Chief Complaint: OUTPATIENT CARDIOLOGIST:  Dr [**Last Name (STitle) **], [**Location (un) 2408**]
   Cardiology
   .
   PCP:[**Name10 (NameIs) **] [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Name (STitle) 13964**]
   .
   CHIEF COMPLAINT: respiratory distress
   24 Hour Events:
 EKG - At [**2109-2-2**] 09:40 AM
 OR SENT - At [**2109-2-2**] 11:22 AM
 ARTERIAL LINE - START [**2109-2-2**] 01:47 PM
 OR RECEIVED - At [**2109-2-2**] 01:47 PM
 MULTI LUMEN - START [**2109-2-2**] 01:48 PM
 INVASIVE VENTILATION - START [**2109-2-2**] 01:50 PM
 INVASIVE VENTILATION - STOP [**2109-2-2**] 04:00 PM
   .
   HISTORY OF PRESENTING ILLNESS:72M h/o CAD s/p MI s/p CABG (6), systolic
   CHF (EF 15%) s/p ICD, atrial fibrillation, diabetes mellitus admitted,
   sleep apnea on BIPAP to SICU from OSH([**Location (un) 2408**]) with confusion s/p fall
   found on Head CT to have subdural hematoma s/p evacuation/burr hole. On
   arrival was in afib managed with IV metoprolol given NPO and on BIPAP
   s/p extubation post burrhole/evacuation. Cards consult for assitance
   with cardiac management given hx, with assessment that there was no
   evidence CHF/active ischemia and to continue cards meds (plavix/asa
   were being held given head bleed. Had been holding his lasix and
   antihtn's (lisinopril 10, carvedilol 12.5) and pt received 3L IV fluids
   in OR. Overnight became more tachypneic with poor UOP received 10mg IV
   lasix an [**9-5**] 9am then another 20mg IV with only small increase in UOP
   but hypotensive to mid 80s with boluses. Noted by cards on f/u to be
   clinically volume overload consistent with CVP of 24 with Bedside Echo
   poor quality but showed Afib, stable severe LV dilation with EF 15%,
   elevated LA pressure, 1 + MR with no priors for comparison. Initial CXR
   on admission showed pulmonary congestion, repeat CXR at this point did
   not show any change. Also noted to have worsening Cr from 1.3 on
   admission to 1.9 currently. He was at this point admitted to CCU
   service for management heart failure.
   .
   On transfer to cards he was +ve 1500cc for the day with CVP 24.
   Switched to lasix gtt, with goal UOP 100-150cc/hr. He restarted his
   carvedilol although lisinopril was held given his renal failure.
   .
   On review of systems,per daughter pt had "platelet allergy in
   ambulance, hx unclear. he denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, deep
   venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery,
   myalgias, joint pains, cough, hemoptysis, black stools or red stools.he
   denies recent fevers, chills or rigors. S/he denies exertional buttock
   or calf pain. All of the other review of systems were negative.
   .
   Cardiac review of systems is notable for absence of chest pain, dyspnea
   on exertion, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, ankle edema,
   palpitations, syncope or presyncope.
   .
   PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: DM, CAD s/p MI, CABG, Afib, CHF w/ EF 15% s/p
   ICD, sleep apnea on BIPAP
   Cardiac Risk Factors include diabetes, CAD.
   .
   HOME MEDICATIONS: ASA 81 mg, Carvedilol 12.5 mg [**Hospital1 **], Lisinopril 10 mg
   daily, Plavix 75 mg daily, Lasix 40 mg [**Hospital1 **], Zocor 40 mg q day, KCl 20
   meq daily, Prilosec 20 mg daily, MVI, Insulin Novolog 70/30
   .
   Meds on transfer:
   Furosemide 1-5 mg/hr IV DRIP INFUSION
   titrate to net NEGATIVE 50-100cc per hour
   Heparin 5000 UNIT SC TID
   Clopidogrel 75 mg PO/NG DAILY
   Phenytoin Sodium Extended 100 mg PO TID
   Ondansetron 4 mg IV Q8H:PRN nausea
   HydrALAzine 10 mg IV Q6H SBP>160
   Acetaminophen 325-650 mg PO/NG Q6H:PRN fever/pain
   Senna 1 TAB PO/NG [**Hospital1 7**]
   Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID
   Simvastatin 40 mg PO/NG DAILY  [**2-2**] @ 1138 View
   Omeprazole 20 mg PO DAILY
   Carvedilol 12.5 mg PO/NG [**Hospital1 7**]
   .
   ALLERGIES: NKDA
   SOCIAL HISTORY: Retired, lives with wife. In dependant of ADLs. Smoker
   in past.
   .
   FAMILY HISTORY: Noncontributory for CAD
   . .
   LABS/STUDIEs:
   TELEMETRY: AF intermittenly paced
   ECG [**2109-2-2**]: AF with intermitted ventricular pacing. LBBB in native
   beats.
   Head CT:
   1. Large lentiform predominantly hypodense extra-axial collection along
   the left cerebral hemisphere, with hyperdense rim and internal
   septations, compatible with chronic subdural hematoma. This collection
   causes substantial mass effect, including rightward subfalcine
   herniation and early left uncal herniation. Findings not changed from
   one day prior.
   2. Hypodense evolving subacute posterior right temporal lobe infarct,
   in the territory of the right MCA, unchanged.
   .
   CXR: A dual-lead pacemaker generator overlies the left upper
   hemithorax, with leads terminating in the right atrium and right
   ventricle. Median sternotomy wires are in place. Lung volumes are low.
   Bilaterally, there is perihilar vascular congestion. The heart is
   enlarged. There may be a trace right effusion, but there is no left
   pleural effusion or consolidation. There is no pneumothorax.
   IMPRESSION: Cardiomegaly and pulmonary congestion.
   .
   2D-ECHOCARDIOGRAM:  [**2109-2-3**]
   The left atrium is elongated. The right atrium is moderately dilated.
   Left ventricular wall thicknesses are normal. The left ventricular
   cavity is severely dilated. Due to suboptimal technical quality, a
   focal wall motion abnormality cannot be fully excluded. Overall left
   ventricular systolic function is severely depressed (LVEF= 15 %). The
   right ventricular cavity is moderately dilated with mild global free
   wall hypokinesis. The ascending aorta is mildly dilated. The aortic
   valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened. No aortic regurgitation is
   seen. The mitral valve leaflets are moderately thickened. Mild (1+)
   mitral regurgitation is seen. [Due to acoustic shadowing, the severity
   of mitral regurgitation may be significantly UNDERestimated.] The left
   ventricular inflow pattern suggests a restrictive filling abnormality,
   with elevated left atrial pressure. There is a very small pericardial
   effusion.
   .
   LABORATORY DATA:
   See below.
   Allergies:
   No Known Drug Allergies
   Last dose of Antibiotics:

 SUBDURAL HEMORRHAGE (SDH)

   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 72M h/o CAD s/p MI s/p CABG (6), systolic CHF (EF

   If unable to tolerate BP wise consider milrinone for ionotrope assisted

   Continue diuresis with lasix
   check 9pm electrolytes
   Continue to trend Cr.
   Consider renal consult if not improving in am.
   .
   # subdural hematoma s/p burrhole/evacuation.
   Per daughter [**Name (NI) 13965**] in am, sundowns
   -serial neuro checks
   -avoid benzo's, frequent reorientation
   restarting ASA/plavix in am
   appreciate neuro recs.
   .
   # Sleep Apnea: CPAP o/n
   .
   COMM: Wife: [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 13966**]: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 13967**].
   .

4. The patient's renal function is compromised, with a creatinine level of 1.9 mg/dL and a urine output of 1500cc on transfer to the cardiology service. He is receiving diuretic therapy with Lasix and has a goal of negative 1L fluid balance.
5. The patient's neurological status is stable, with no changes in his level of consciousness or neurological deficits.
6. The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin-T and CK-MB levels, indicating possible cardiac injury.
7. The patient's ECG shows atrial fibrillation with intermittent ventricular pacing, and his echocardiogram shows severe left ventricular dilation with an EF of 15%.
8. The patient's plan includes continued diuresis with Lasix, close monitoring of his fluid balance, and regular checks of his electrolyte levels. He is also scheduled to receive a renal consult if his creatinine level does not improve.

Potential medical complications that may arise in this patient include:

1. Worsening of cardiac function: The patient's EF is already severely depressed, and further worsening of cardiac function could lead to cardiogenic shock.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's oxygen saturation is stable on BIPAP, but he may require further respiratory support if his respiratory status deteriorates.
3. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is already elevated, and further worsening of his renal function could lead to acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.
4. Neurological deterioration: The patient's neurological status is stable, but he may require further monitoring and treatment if he experiences any changes in his level of consciousness or neurological deficits.
5. Infection: The patient's indwelling catheters and drains may increase his risk of infection, which could lead to sepsis or organ failure.
6. Bleeding: The patient's history of bleeding complications, including the subdural hematoma, may increase his risk of further bleeding complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding or hematuria.
7. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's diuretic therapy and electrolyte imbalances may increase his risk of electrolyte imbalance, which could lead to cardiac arrhythmias or other complications.

Based on this information, I recommend the following:

1. Continue close monitoring of the patient's cardiac function, respiratory status, and renal function.
2. Continue diuresis with Lasix and monitor the patient's fluid balance closely.
3. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels regularly and adjust his medications as necessary to prevent electrolyte imbalance.

5. Monitor the patient's neurological status closely and adjust his medications as necessary to prevent neurological deterioration.
6. Consider further respiratory support if the patient's respiratory status deteriorates.
7. Monitor the patient's indwelling catheters and drains closely to prevent infection.
8. Consider a bleeding consult if the patient experiences any bleeding complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 72-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), previous myocardial infarction (MI), and coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG). He has been admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) due to a subdural hematoma (SDH) following a burr hole evacuation. The patient has been experiencing respiratory distress, with increased oxygen requirements and apneic episodes. He has also been experiencing cardiac issues, including atrial fibrillation and a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 15%.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count (WBC), hemoglobin (Hb), and creatinine (Cr) levels. His electrolyte levels are within normal limits, except for a slightly elevated potassium (K+) level. His troponin-T level is elevated, indicating possible cardiac ischemia.

The patient's medical plan includes:

1. Volume overload management: The patient is being treated with lasix to promote diuresis and reduce fluid overload.
2. Cardiac management: The patient is being treated with carvedilol, a beta blocker, to manage his atrial fibrillation and heart failure.
3. Renal management: The patient is being treated with lasix to promote diuresis and reduce fluid overload, and his electrolyte levels are being closely monitored.
4. Sleep apnea management: The patient is being treated with CPAP therapy to manage his sleep apnea.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory distress could worsen, leading to respiratory failure.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation and heart failure could worsen, leading to cardiac complications such as cardiogenic shock.
3. Renal failure: The patient's elevated creatinine level and decreased urine output could indicate impending renal failure.
4. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and possible infection could lead to sepsis.
5. Neurological complications: The patient's subdural hematoma and possible bleeding could lead to neurological complications such as increased intracranial pressure or brain herniation.

Based on the patient's condition and medical plan, it is essential to closely monitor his vital signs, laboratory results, and response to treatment to prevent and manage potential complications.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient, a 72-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), post-myocardial infarction (MI), and post-coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), is being treated for a subdural hematoma (SDH) and volume overload. The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation (Afib) and is on an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD).

The patient's condition has been stable, with improvements in respiratory support and urine output. However, the patient continues to experience tachypnea, tachycardia, and hypoxia, which may be related to his underlying cardiac condition and volume overload.

The patient's laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count (WBC), with a trend downward, and an elevated troponin-T level, suggesting ongoing cardiac stress. His blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine (Cr) levels are elevated, consistent with acute kidney injury.

The patient's medical plan includes diuresis with furosemide (Lasix), continuation of carvedilol, and restart of aspirin and clopidogrel. The patient is also being treated for sleep apnea with continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP).

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's underlying CAD and Afib increase his risk of cardiac complications, such as myocardial infarction, cardiac arrhythmias, and heart failure.
2. Respiratory complications: The patient's tachypnea and hypoxia may lead to respiratory failure, which could require mechanical ventilation.
3. Renal complications: The patient's acute kidney injury may progress to chronic kidney disease or require dialysis.
4. Neurological complications: The patient's SDH and Afib may lead to neurological complications, such as seizures, stroke, or cognitive impairment.
5. Infection: The patient's immunocompromised state and presence of indwelling catheters increase his risk of infection.

Based on the patient's condition and medical plan, I recommend continued close monitoring and management of his cardiac, respiratory, and renal status. The patient's laboratory results should be closely monitored, and adjustments made to his medical plan as necessary.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with a subdural hematoma (SDH) and a history of cardiac disease. The patient's condition has deteriorated over the past 24 hours, with increased respiratory distress, apneic episodes, and tachypnea. The patient's blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygen saturation are within normal limits, but their respiratory rate is elevated. The patient's white blood cell count is trending down from 19.8 to 16.7.

The patient's medications include phenytoin, which was switched to keppra due to subtherapeutic levels. The patient also received antibiotics, including cefazolin, and was given furosemide, metoprolol, and heparin sodium.

The patient's lab results show an elevated troponin-T level, indicating potential cardiac damage. The patient's lactic acid level is elevated at 1.4 mmol/L, suggesting metabolic acidosis. The patient's albumin level is low at 3.8 g/dL, indicating malnutrition.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's increased respiratory distress and apneic episodes may lead to respiratory failure, which can be life-threatening.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of cardiac disease and elevated troponin-T level may increase the risk of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiac arrest.
3. Infection: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and decreased platelet count may increase the risk of infection.
4. Malnutrition: The patient's low albumin level and decreased caloric intake may lead to malnutrition, which can worsen the patient's overall condition.
5. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's elevated lactic acid level may lead to metabolic acidosis, which can cause a range of symptoms, including confusion, agitation, and respiratory distress.

Given the patient's complex medical condition and potential complications, it is essential to closely monitor their condition and adjust their treatment plan as needed to prevent further deterioration and improve their chances of recovery.

Summary:

The patient is a 72-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), myocardial infarction (MI), and cardiac arrhythmia (atrial fibrillation). He is currently in the ICU with systolic heart failure (EF 15%) and volume overload. He has undergone coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) and has an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD). The patient has also had a subdural hematoma with burr hole/evacuation.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 98 bpm and blood pressure of 89/67 mmHg. His oxygen saturation is 95% on a bipap mask. His respiratory support includes oxygen delivery via a bipap mask and continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) at night.

The patient's laboratory results show normal white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and platelet count. His creatinine is elevated at 1.9 mg/dL, and his blood urea nitrogen (BUN) is 35 mg/dL. His troponin-T is 0.04 ng/mL, and his lactate acid is 1.9 mmol/L.

The patient's medical plan includes diuresis with furosemide (Lasix) and consideration of milrinone for inotrope-assisted diuresis if unable to tolerate. He is also receiving prophylactic anticoagulation with heparin and stress ulcer prophylaxis with proton pump inhibitors.

Potential medical complications:

1. Volume overload: The patient's current volume overload could lead to further complications such as pulmonary edema, respiratory failure, or cardiac arrhythmias.
2. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and current arrhythmia could lead to further complications such as cardiac arrest or stroke.
3. Renal failure: The patient's elevated creatinine and BUN levels could indicate acute kidney injury, which could lead to further complications such as electrolyte imbalances, acidosis, or anemia.
4. Subdural hematoma: The patient's history of subdural hematoma could lead to further complications such as recurrent bleeding, hydrocephalus, or brain injury.
5. Sleep apnea: The patient's history of sleep apnea could lead to further complications such as respiratory failure, cardiac arrhythmias, or sudden death.
6. Infection: The patient's current ICU stay could lead to further complications such as sepsis, pneumonia, or urinary tract infection.
7. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of cardiac arrhythmias and current anticoagulation therapy could lead to further complications such as gastrointestinal bleeding or hematuria.

Summary:

The patient, a 72-year-old male, is a post-cardiac arrest patient with a history of coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction, and cardiac surgery. He is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) with acute on chronic renal failure, atrial fibrillation, and chronic heart failure. He has been experiencing volume overload, which was treated with diuretics, and has been showing signs of agitation, tachypnea, and tachycardia.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.4C (97.5F)
* Heart rate: 98 bpm (94-125 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 89/67 mmHg (72-123/92 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 34 breaths per minute (18-42 breaths per minute)
* Oxygen saturation: 95%
* Central venous pressure: 9 mmHg (9-18 mmHg)

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 19.8 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 14.1 g/dL
* Platelet count: 266 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 1.9 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 35 mg/dL
* Electrolytes: sodium 139 mmol/L, potassium 4.4 mmol/L, chloride 95 mmol/L, bicarbonate 24 mmol/L

Potential medical complications that can arise:

Summary:

The patient is a 24-hour-old post-operative patient in the ICU who underwent a procedure. They have a history of cardiac issues and were admitted with tachycardia, hypertension, and tachypnea. Overnight, they became more dyspneic and agitated, requiring increased lasix and diuril dosages. Their EKG showed a possible atrial fibrillation with intermittent ventricular pacing. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.4C, heart rate of 98 bpm, and blood pressure of 89/67 mmHg. Their respiratory support includes a bipap mask with an SpO2 of 95%. They have received multiple lab tests, including blood chemistry, complete blood counts, and coagulation studies, which are within normal limits.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac Complications: The patient's history of cardiac issues and the possibility of atrial fibrillation with intermittent ventricular pacing increases their risk of cardiac complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias, heart failure, or cardiac arrest.
2. Respiratory Complications: The patient's respiratory support with a bipap mask and their history of tachypnea increase their risk of respiratory complications, such as respiratory failure, pneumonia, or acute respiratory distress syndrome.
3. Neurological Complications: The patient's neurological status is unclear due to their lack of response to stimuli, and they are at risk of developing neurological complications, such as seizures, stroke, or brain edema.
4. Infection: The patient's immunosuppressed state and history of cardiac surgery increase their risk of infection, particularly sepsis or pneumonia.
5. Bleeding: The patient's coagulopathy and history of cardiac surgery increase their risk of bleeding complications, such as hemorrhage or hematoma.
6. Metabolic Complications: The patient's history of cardiac surgery and their current metabolic status increase their risk of metabolic complications, such as hyperglycemia, hyperkalemia, or hypocalcemia.
7. Nutritional Complications: The patient's inability to eat and their history of cardiac surgery increase their risk of nutritional complications, such as malnutrition, electrolyte imbalances, or vitamin deficiencies.

The patient's respiratory status is stable, with an SpO2 of 95% and no significant changes in their ABG values.

The patient's cardiac status is of concern, with frequent PVCs and a history of atrial fibrillation. The EKG shows no significant changes, but the patient's CVP is elevated, and they are receiving IV diuril to manage fluid overload.

The patient's neurologic status is stable, with normal orientation and no signs of increased intracranial pressure. The patient's skin is cool to the touch, and their extremities are cool with dopplerable pulses.

Laboratory results show normal to elevated values for various biomarkers, including troponin-T, CK, and CKMB. The patient's electrolyte values are within normal limits, with the exception of a slightly elevated potassium level.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and frequent PVCs increases their risk of developing cardiac arrhythmias.
2. Fluid overload: The patient's elevated CVP and fluid balance data suggest the possibility of fluid overload, which can lead to pulmonary edema and other complications.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but they are receiving oxygen therapy, which increases their risk of respiratory failure.
4. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and C-reactive protein level suggest the possibility of sepsis, which can lead to multi-organ dysfunction.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of gastrointestinal bleeding and their use of anticoagulant therapy increase their risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
6. Renal failure: The patient's elevated creatinine level and decreased urine output suggest the possibility of renal failure, which can lead to electrolyte imbalances and other complications.
7. Infection: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and C-reactive protein level suggest the possibility of infection, which can lead to sepsis and multi-organ dysfunction.

In conclusion, the patient's condition is stable, but they are at risk for various medical complications. Close monitoring and management of their condition are necessary to prevent these complications and improve their outcomes.

Summary:

The patient is a 72-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction, and chronic heart failure, who has undergone coronary artery bypass grafting and implantation of an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD). He has also had a subdural hematoma and has developed atrial fibrillation with intermittent ventricular pacing. The patient is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) with a diagnosis of volume overload and acute on chronic renal failure.

24-hour events:

* The patient became more dyspneic and agitated overnight, with increased heart rate and blood pressure. He was given a lasix bolus and IV diuril, which improved his symptoms.
* The patient's cardiac rhythm was interrogated, but the results were unclear due to his atrial fibrillation.
* The patient was started on plavix 3 days post-procedure and switched from dilantin to keppra.
* The patient's neurosurgery team put in orders for serial neuro checks and avoidance of benzodiazepines.

Potential medical complications:

* Volume overload: The patient's volume overload is likely due to his atrial fibrillation and poor forward flow, which can lead to worsening of his chronic heart failure and increased risk of cardiac arrest.
* Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient's acute kidney injury is likely due to his volume overload and atrial fibrillation, which can lead to further worsening of his kidney function and increased risk of chronic kidney disease.
* Sleep apnea: The patient's sleep apnea is likely due to his chronic heart failure and atrial fibrillation, which can lead to further worsening of his symptoms and increased risk of cardiovascular events.
* Infection: The patient's subdural hematoma and atrial fibrillation increase his risk of developing an infection, which can lead to further complications and increased risk of mortality.

Recommendations:

* Continue diuresis with lasix and monitor the patient's volume status.
* Continue to trend the patient's creatinine levels and consider renal consult if not improving.
* Monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and consider cardioversion if his atrial fibrillation persists.
* Continue to monitor the patient's neuro status and consider serial neuro checks.
* Consider restarting ASA and plavix in the morning.
* Continue to trend the patient's glucose levels and consider adjusting his insulin regimen as needed.
* Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and consider adjusting his medication regimen as needed.

Summary:

The patient, a 72-year-old male, is a post-cardiac arrest patient with a history of coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction, and coronary artery bypass grafting. He has a left ventricular ejection fraction of 15% and is in atrial fibrillation. He was admitted to the ICU after a subdural hematoma evacuation procedure and has been experiencing volume overload, which was treated with diuretics and lasix. He has also been experiencing tachypnea, tachycardia, and decreased urine output.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 36.6C, heart rate of 99 bpm, blood pressure of 110/81 mmHg, respiratory rate of 38 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 74%. His central venous pressure (CVP) is elevated at 15 mmHg. His laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count, creatinine, and blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels, as well as a decreased hemoglobin level.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's tachypnea and decreased oxygen saturation may indicate respiratory failure, which can lead to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and respiratory arrest.
2. Cardiac failure: The patient's history of coronary artery disease, atrial fibrillation, and left ventricular ejection fraction of 15% puts him at high risk for cardiac failure, which can lead to cardiogenic shock and cardiac arrest.
3. Renal failure: The patient's elevated creatinine and BUN levels may indicate acute kidney injury, which can lead to chronic kidney disease and end-stage renal disease.
4. Infection: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and decreased oxygen saturation may indicate infection, which can lead to sepsis and organ dysfunction.
5. Neurological complications: The patient's history of subdural hematoma evacuation and atrial fibrillation puts him at risk for neurological complications, such as stroke and seizures.
6. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and warfarin use puts him at risk for gastrointestinal bleeding, which can lead to hemorrhagic shock and death.
7. Thrombosis: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and warfarin use puts him at risk for thrombosis, which can lead to pulmonary embolism and death.

In conclusion, this patient is at high risk for multiple medical complications, including respiratory failure, cardiac failure, renal failure, infection, neurological complications, gastrointestinal bleeding, and thrombosis. Close monitoring and management of these complications are necessary to prevent morbidity and mortality.

Summary:

The patient is a 72-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), myocardial infarction (MI), and coronary artery bypass graft (CABG). He has a systolic heart failure (CHF) with an ejection fraction (EF) of 15%. He also has atrial fibrillation and has undergone a burr hole/evacuation for a subdural hematoma. The patient is currently in the ICU with a central line and is receiving various medications, including lasix, carvedilol, and Keppra.

The patient's condition has been stable, but he has developed some new symptoms, including increased agitation, tachypnea, and decreasing urine output. His vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 36.6C (97.8F)
* Heart rate: 99 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 110/81 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 38 breaths per minute (bpm)
* Oxygen saturation: 74%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: CVP 15 mmHg, HR 99 bpm

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Creatinine: 1.6 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 38 mg/dL
* Electrolytes: Na 139 mmol/L, K 4.2 mmol/L, Cl 102 mmol/L
* Glucose: 100 mg/dL

The patient's medical conditions include:

* CHF
* Atrial fibrillation
* CAD
* MI
* CABG
* Subdural hematoma
* Sleep apnea
* Acute on chronic renal failure
* DM

The patient's plan includes:

* Continue lasix gtt with goal I + O negative 2 L today
* Change carvedilol to metoprolol for rate control with less antihypertensive effect and uptitrate as needed
* No Coumadin for now; can consider this in 3 weeks (after neurosurg f/u) for neurosurgery
* Continue simvastatin
* Change carvedilol to metoprolol as above
* Continue diuresis
* Continue to trend creatinine
* [**Hospital1 7**] lytes during diuresis
* Continue insulin NPH + Humalog sliding scale at current dose
* Neuro checks q4 hrs
* Appreciate neuro sx input
* Neurosurg f/u in [**12-26**] weeks as outpatient
* Repeat head CT this a.m.

Potential Medical Complications:

* Volume overload: The patient's volume status is still overloaded, and he may require further diuresis to manage this condition.
* Atrial fibrillation: The patient's tachycardia may be contributing to his symptoms, and he may require rate control with medication.
* Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is still elevated, and he may require further management to prevent further decline in renal function.
* DM: The patient's fasting hypoglycemia has resolved, but he may require continued management to prevent future episodes.
* Subdural hematoma: The patient's neurologic exam is stable, but he may require further monitoring and management to prevent further complications.
* Sleep apnea: The patient's sleep apnea may require further management to prevent further episodes.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.5C, heart rate of 86 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 99/67 mmHg. She is receiving oxygen therapy and has a SpO2 of 95%. Her cardiac rhythm is ventricular-paced, and her CVP is 11 mmHg.

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Subdural hemorrhage
* CAD with catheterization deferred due to contrast-induced nephropathy
* DM
* HTN
* CVA

The patient's medications include:

* ASA 325mg daily
* Labetalol
* Plavix
* High-dose statin
* Hydral 10mg IV x1
* Norvasc
* Isordil
* Lisinopril (held)

* Novolog SS

The patient's plan includes:

* Continue tight BP control
* Continue prehydration/mucomyst

* Check urine lytes

* Follow fluid status/exam closely

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Worsening of renal failure
* Cardiac complications due to restrictive cardiomyopathy
* Increased risk of bleeding due to subdural hemorrhage
* Complications related to DM, HTN, and CVA
* Infections due to immunosuppression
* Gastrointestinal complications due to medication use and bowel regimen
* Pulmonary complications due to oxygen therapy and respiratory support.

Summary:

The patient is a 65-year-old woman with a history of coronary artery disease, diabetes, hypertension, and cerebrovascular accident. She was admitted for ASA desensitization prior to cardiac catheterization, which was deferred due to contrast-induced nephropathy. The patient has acute renal failure, acute coronary syndrome, and subdural hemorrhage. She is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) and is receiving treatment for her various conditions.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine level is 1.9, and she is at risk for further deterioration of her renal function. Close monitoring of her creatinine levels and urine output is necessary.
2. Cardiomyopathy: The patient's ejection fraction is 55%, and she has diastolic heart failure. This increases her risk of cardiac complications, such as heart failure and arrhythmias.
3. Subdural Hemorrhage: The patient has a subdural hemorrhage, which can lead to increased intracranial pressure and neurological complications.
4. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is not well-controlled, and she is at risk for further hypertension-related complications, such as cardiac failure and stroke.
5. Infection: The patient is at risk for infection due to her indwelling catheter and other medical devices.
6. Respiratory Failure: The patient's oxygen saturation is 95%, and she is at risk for respiratory failure, especially if her underlying lung disease worsens.
7. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient is at risk for gastrointestinal complications, such as nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea, due to her medication regimen and underlying medical conditions.
8. Neurological Complications: The patient's history of cerebrovascular accident and subdural hemorrhage increases her risk of neurological complications, such as seizures and stroke.

Recommendations:

1. Continue close monitoring of the patient's creatinine levels and urine output to assess the progression of her renal failure.
2. Adjust the patient's medication regimen to better control her hypertension and cardiac conditions.
3. Consider restarting lactulose post-catheterization to prevent constipation.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust her medication regimen as necessary to prevent further neurological complications.
5. Consider referring the patient to a nephrologist for further management of her renal failure.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust her oxygen therapy as necessary to prevent respiratory failure.
7. Consider referring the patient to a gastroenterologist for further management of her gastrointestinal symptoms.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's pain levels and adjust her pain medication regimen as necessary to prevent further pain-related complications.

   24 Hour Events:
 MULTI LUMEN - STOP [**2109-2-6**] 12:00 PM
 EKG - At [**2109-2-6**] 03:21 PM
   Overnight Events:
   - his CVL was removed in the morning
   - he got 5 mg metolazone in addition to 500 mg of Diuril in the
   morning, as well as a 20 mg lasix bolus
   - in the afternoon patient looked increasingly worse- skin mottled,
   perioral cyanosis, low urine output, agitated; repeat electrolytes
   showed worsening renal function; ABG looked fine with good oxygenation,
   stable pH, although lactate was elevated to 2.7; CXR looked unchanged;
   EKG and cardiac enzymes unchanged
   - we stopped his diuretics
   - after much discussion we decided to give him back some fluids
   (thinking he was intravascularly dry from overdiuresis the last two
   days); we gave him 250 cc IV bolus x2 of normal saline
   - for his respiratory agitation, he got 0.5 mg IV morphine x2
   - we changed PO metoprolol to IV given that he was too agitated to
   tolerate pos; we think better rate control will improve his perfusion,
   and stopping the diuretics may allow us to increase his BB
   - with the fluids and morphine, he calmed down, UOP increased, and his
   overall clinical status improved

Summary:

The patient is a 25-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of acute renal failure, restrictive cardiomyopathy, and subdural hemorrhage. He has been receiving diuretics, morphine, and other medications to manage his symptoms. Over the past 24 hours, the patient's condition has worsened, with increased agitation, decreased urine output, and worsening renal function. Despite stopping diuretics and administering IV fluids, the patient's condition improved with the administration of morphine and IV fluids.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure is a life-threatening condition that requires close monitoring and management. If left untreated, it can lead to electrolyte imbalances, acidosis, and cardiovascular instability.
2. Cardiomyopathy: The patient's restrictive cardiomyopathy is a serious condition that can lead to heart failure, arrhythmias, and even death if left untreated. Close monitoring of cardiac function and management of symptoms are essential.
3. Subdural hemorrhage: The patient's subdural hemorrhage is a serious condition that requires close monitoring and management. If left untreated, it can lead to increased intracranial pressure, brain herniation, and even death.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's worsening respiratory status is a concern, particularly with the administration of morphine, which can depress respiratory function. Close monitoring of respiratory status and management of symptoms are essential.
5. Electrolyte imbalances: The patient's worsening renal function and administration of diuretics can lead to electrolyte imbalances, particularly hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia. Close monitoring of electrolyte levels and management of symptoms are essential.
6. Infection: The patient's subdural hemorrhage and acute renal failure increase his risk of developing an infection, particularly pneumonia and urinary tract infections. Close monitoring of vital signs and laboratory results is essential to detect early signs of infection.
7. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's cardiomyopathy and acute renal failure increase his risk of developing cardiovascular instability, particularly hypotension and cardiac arrhythmias. Close monitoring of vital signs and laboratory results is essential to detect early signs of cardiovascular instability.

Recommendations:

1. Continue close monitoring of the patient's renal function, cardiac function, and respiratory status.
2. Manage the patient's symptoms with medications and other interventions as necessary.
3. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and manage any imbalances that develop.
4. Monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results to detect early signs of infection and cardiovascular instability.
5. Consider consulting with a cardiologist and/or nephrologist to further manage the patient's cardiomyopathy and acute renal failure.
6. Consider consulting with a neurosurgeon to further manage the patient's subdural hemorrhage.
7. Continue to educate the patient and his family about his condition, treatment options, and prognosis.

   baseline of 1.2. Likely prerenal from poor forward flow.
   - continue diuresis
   - continue to trend creatinine
   - [**Hospital1 7**] lytes during diuresis
   .
   # DM: Fasting hypoglycemia has resolved with decreased insulin dosing.
   - continue insulin NPH + Humalog sliding scale at current dose

   - neuro checks q4 hrs
   - appreciate neuro sx input
   - neurosurg f/u in [**12-26**] weeks as outpatient
   - per neurosurg,  continue Keppra for total 7 days. Stables will come

   - repeat head CT this a.m.
   .

Summary:

The patient is a 72-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) and atrial fibrillation (AF) who underwent cardiac bypass surgery (CABG) and implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) placement. He was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with symptoms of fluid overload, which was likely caused by excessive IV fluids during surgery. The patient's condition worsened overnight, with signs of poor perfusion, agitation, and worsening renal function. He received IV fluids, diuretics, and vasopressors to improve perfusion and reduce fluid overload. The patient's laboratory results show elevated creatinine and lactate levels, indicating acute kidney injury and metabolic acidosis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac Complications:
	* Tachycardia and atrial fibrillation may exacerbate cardiac symptoms and increase the risk of cardiac arrest.
	* Poor forward flow and fluid overload may lead to worsening heart failure and increased risk of cardiac complications.
2. Renal Complications:
	* Acute kidney injury may progress to chronic kidney disease if not managed promptly.
	* Fluid overload and diuretic therapy may lead to electrolyte imbalances and worsening renal function.
3. Metabolic Complications:
	* Metabolic acidosis may worsen if not managed with proper ventilation and electrolyte replacement.
	* Hyperglycemia may develop if insulin dosing is not adjusted properly.
4. Neurological Complications:
	* Subdural hematoma may worsen if not managed promptly, leading to increased risk of intracranial hypertension and neurological deterioration.
	* Sedation and anesthesia may be necessary to manage agitation and prevent further neurological deterioration.
5. Respiratory Complications:
	* Pneumonia or ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) may develop if proper respiratory care is not provided.
	* Respiratory failure may occur if oxygenation and ventilation are not managed properly.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's condition requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications. The plan includes:

1. Continue diuretic therapy to manage fluid overload and improve perfusion.
2. Adjust insulin dosing to manage hyperglycemia.
3. Monitor and manage atrial fibrillation and tachycardia with rate control medications.
4. Continue prophylaxis for DVT and stress ulcer prevention.
5. Repeat head CT scan to monitor for subdural hematoma progression.
6. Monitor for signs of respiratory failure and pneumonia.
7. Continue to trend creatinine and electrolyte levels to monitor for worsening renal function.
8. Adjust medication dosing and therapy as needed to manage the patient's condition.

Summary:

The patient is a 72-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction, and cardiac surgery, who is currently in the ICU with a subdural hematoma and atrial fibrillation. He has been experiencing volume overload, which has led to worsening renal function and elevated lactate levels. The patient has been treated with diuretics, but his condition has not improved. He has also been experiencing tachycardia, which is contributing to his symptoms and further fluid overload.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Volume overload: The patient's condition is likely to worsen if not managed properly, leading to further fluid overload, respiratory failure, and cardiac compromise.
2. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, and his condition may worsen if not managed properly, leading to acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.
3. Cardiac compromise: The patient's tachycardia and atrial fibrillation may lead to cardiac compromise, including heart failure, arrhythmias, and even cardiac arrest.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status may deteriorate if not managed properly, leading to respiratory failure and the need for mechanical ventilation.
5. Neurological compromise: The patient's subdural hematoma and atrial fibrillation may lead to neurological compromise, including stroke, seizures, and even death.

Recommendations:

1. Continue diuretic therapy to manage volume overload and improve renal function.
2. Monitor the patient's cardiac status closely and consider adjusting his medications to control his tachycardia and atrial fibrillation.
3. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and consider adjusting his respiratory therapy to improve his oxygenation and ventilation.
4. Monitor the patient's neurological status closely and consider adjusting his medications to manage his subdural hematoma and atrial fibrillation.
5. Consider consulting with a cardiologist and/or a neurosurgeon to optimize the patient's care and management.

   his fluid status
   - consider repeat echo to evaluate cardiac function
   .

   symptoms, resulting in poor forward flow and further fluid overload.
   - continue metoprolol for rate control, uptitrate as needed
   - no Coumadin for now; can consider this in 3 weeks (after neurosurg
   f/u)
   - attempt to touch base with neurosurgery re: anticoagulation
   .
   # CORONARIES: CAD s/p CABG. Pt denies any chest pain at this time.
   - No apparent h/o PCI, so can change Plavix to aspirin (if okay from
   neurosurgical perspective)
   - continue simvastatin, metoprolol
   .
   #  Acute on Chronic renal failure: Cr 2.1 today, recent baseline of
   1.2. Likely prerenal from poor forward flow with superimposed
   overdiuresis.
   - continue to trend creatinine
   - holding further diuresis, as above
   - consider urine lytes if creatinine does not improve
   .
   # DM: Fasting hypoglycemia has resolved with decreased insulin dosing.
   - continue insulin NPH + Humalog sliding scale at current dose
   .
   # Subdural Hematoma s/p Burrhole/Evacuation: Neurologic exam stable.
   - neuro checks q4 hrs
   - appreciate neuro sx input
   - neurosurg f/u in [**12-26**] weeks as outpatient
   - per neurosurg,  continue Keppra for total 7 days. Staples will come
   out after total 10 days
   - repeat head CT today
   .

   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:  Regular insulin sliding scale

   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: SQ UF Heparin
   Stress ulcer: PPI
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition:ICU

Summary:

The patient is a 72-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction, and cardiac surgery, who presented with systolic heart failure, atrial fibrillation, and subdural hematoma. He was admitted to the ICU for management of volume overload and respiratory distress. The patient's condition has worsened over the past 24 hours, with increasing signs of fluid overload, including cold, clammy, and mottled extremities, perioral cyanosis, and low urine output. His renal function has also deteriorated, with a creatinine level of 2.1 mg/dL.

The patient was initially treated with diuretics, including furosemide and metolazone, but this was stopped due to worsening renal function. He was given a 20 mg lasix bolus, and his fluids were increased to improve perfusion. Morphine was also administered to manage respiratory distress.

The patient's heart rhythm is irregular, and his cardiac enzymes are unchanged. His lactate level is elevated at 2.7 mmol/L. His blood pressure is 99/67 mmHg, and his oxygen saturation is 95%. He is tachycardic and has a heart rate of 86 bpm.

The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, and his electrocardiogram shows no changes. He is on digoxin 0.125 mg daily, but his history of coumadin use is questionable.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Fluid Overload: The patient's condition has worsened over the past 24 hours, with increasing signs of fluid overload. He may be at risk of developing further complications, such as pulmonary edema, respiratory failure, and cardiac tamponade.
2. Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine level is 2.1 mg/dL, and his renal function is likely to deteriorate further if not managed properly. He may be at risk of developing acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.
3. Cardiac Complications: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, and his cardiac enzymes are unchanged. He may be at risk of developing further cardiac complications, such as cardiac tamponade, ventricular fibrillation, or cardiac arrest.
4. Respiratory Complications: The patient has signs of respiratory distress, including tachypnea, hypoxemia, and hypercapnia. He may be at risk of developing further respiratory complications, such as pneumonia, respiratory failure, or acute respiratory distress syndrome.
5. Neurological Complications: The patient has a history of subdural hematoma, and his neurologic exam is stable. However, he may be at risk of developing further neurological complications, such as cerebral edema, intracranial hemorrhage, or seizure.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's fluid status and adjust his fluids as necessary to prevent further fluid overload.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust his diuretic therapy as necessary to prevent further deterioration.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust his anticoagulation therapy as necessary to prevent further cardiac complications.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his oxygen therapy as necessary to prevent further respiratory complications.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust his anticonvulsant therapy as necessary to prevent further neurological complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 72-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction, and cardiac arrest, who underwent coronary artery bypass grafting and implantation of an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD). He was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with systolic congestive heart failure (CHF) and atrial fibrillation, and was found to have a subdural hematoma, which was evacuated via burr hole. He has been experiencing volume overload, which was treated with diuretics, but has since been stopped due to concerns of overdiuresis. He has also been experiencing respiratory distress, which was treated with morphine. His current condition is stable, but he remains at risk for further complications.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac Complications:
	* Tachycardia and atrial fibrillation may lead to poor forward flow and further fluid overload.
	* Coronary artery disease may lead to recurrent myocardial infarction or cardiac arrest.
2. Renal Complications:
	* Acute kidney injury due to prerenal azotemia and overdiuresis.
	* Chronic kidney disease may worsen due to continued fluid overload and potential nephrotoxic medications.
3. Respiratory Complications:
	* Respiratory distress may worsen due to continued fluid overload and potential respiratory muscle weakness.
	* Pneumonia or other respiratory infections may develop due to prolonged ICU stay and immobility.
4. Neurological Complications:
	* Subdural hematoma may recur or worsen due to continued bleeding or rebleeding.
	* Neurological deficits may worsen due to continued compression or edema.
5. Infection Complications:
	* Sepsis may develop due to prolonged ICU stay and immobility.
	* Infections such as pneumonia, urinary tract infections, or bloodstream infections may develop due to prolonged ICU stay and immobility.
6. Metabolic Complications:
	* Hyperglycemia may worsen due to continued insulin resistance and potential insulin deficiency.
	* Hypoglycemia may develop due to continued insulin therapy and potential insulin deficiency.
7. Other Complications:
	* Venous thromboembolism (VTE) may develop due to prolonged immobility and potential hypercoagulability.
	* Stress ulceration may develop due to prolonged ICU stay and immobility.

Overall, the patient remains at risk for further complications due to his underlying medical conditions and prolonged ICU stay. Close monitoring and aggressive management of his condition are necessary to prevent or treat potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 72-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, previous myocardial infarction, and cardiac surgery. He was admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of systolic heart failure, atrial fibrillation, and subdural hematoma. He developed multi-lumen stop, and his condition worsened overnight with signs of fluid overload, including cold, clammy, and mottled extremities, perioral cyanosis, and low urine output. His electrolytes showed worsening renal function, and his cardiac enzymes were unchanged. He was given diuretics, which were later stopped, and he was given fluids and morphine for respiratory distress. His condition improved with these interventions.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Fluid Overload: The patient's condition worsened overnight due to fluid overload, which can lead to respiratory distress, cardiac failure, and increased risk of mortality.
2. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's creatinine levels have increased, indicating acute kidney injury, which can be a complication of fluid overload and cardiac failure.
3. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation can lead to poor forward flow, further exacerbating fluid overload and cardiac failure.
4. Coronary Artery Disease: The patient's history of coronary artery disease and previous myocardial infarction increases his risk of cardiac complications, including cardiac failure and arrhythmias.
5. Subdural Hematoma: The patient's subdural hematoma can lead to neurological complications, including increased intracranial pressure, seizures, and brain herniation.
6. Sleep Apnea: The patient's sleep apnea can lead to respiratory complications, including hypoxia and hypercapnia.
7. Diabetes Mellitus: The patient's diabetes mellitus can lead to complications, including hypoglycemia and hyperglycemia.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's condition is assessed as likely overdiuresed, and his diuretics have been held. His fluid status will be closely monitored, and he will receive fluids as needed. He will also be started on digoxin to control his atrial fibrillation. His cardiac function will be monitored, and he will receive ongoing care for his cardiac, renal, and neurological conditions.

 RENAL FAILURE, ACUTE (ACUTE RENAL FAILURE, ARF)
 CARDIOMYOPATHY, RESTRICTIVE
 SUBDURAL HEMORRHAGE (SDH)
   72 year old man s/p CABG, LVEF = 15%, biventricular pacemaker
 ICD and
   recent subdural hematoma evacuation developed volume overload which
   responded to initial diuresis, but due to hypotension and cool clammy
   extremities, he required a fluid bolus to correct the volume
   depletion.    He is now improved but requiring CPAP for oyxygenation
   due to underlying sleep apnea.  Will continue to observe his mental
   status.
   72M h/o CAD s/p MI s/p CABG, systolic CHF (EF 15%) s/p ICD, atrial
   fibrillation s/p burr hole/evacuation for subdural hematoma with
   development volume overload clinically although no change on CXR.
   Volume overload likely [**12-25**] IV fluids during surgery in the setting of
   having nodal blocking [**Doctor Last Name **] and lasix held.
   .
   # CHF/Fluid Overload: Likely overdiuresed yesterday morning, as
   evidence by cold, clammy, mottled extremities and bump in creatinine.
   Responded well to fluid boluses as well as morphine for respiratory
   distress.
   - hold diuretics and fluids at this point and monitor I/O
   - contine digoxin
   - continue to monitor fluid and respiratory status
   - consider central access if we feel we need a better measurement of
   his fluid status
   - consider repeat echo to evaluate cardiac function
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation: Tachycardia likely contributing to patient
   symptoms, resulting in poor forward flow and further fluid overload.
   - continue metoprolol for rate control, uptitrate as needed
   - no Coumadin for now; can consider this in 3 weeks (after neurosurg
   f/u)
   - attempt to touch base with neurosurgery re: anticoagulation
   .
   # CORONARIES: CAD s/p CABG. Pt denies any chest pain at this time.
   - No apparent h/o PCI, so can change Plavix to aspirin (if okay from
   neurosurgical perspective)
   - continue simvastatin, metoprolol
   .
   #  Acute on Chronic renal failure: Cr 2.1 today, recent baseline of
   1.2. Likely prerenal from poor forward flow with superimposed
   overdiuresis.
   - continue to trend creatinine
   - holding further diuresis, as above
   - consider urine lytes if creatinine does not improve
   .
   # DM: Fasting hypoglycemia has resolved with decreased insulin dosing.
   - continue insulin NPH + Humalog sliding scale at current dose
   .
   # Subdural Hematoma s/p Burrhole/Evacuation: Neurologic exam stable.
   - neuro checks q4 hrs
   - appreciate neuro sx input
   - neurosurg f/u in [**12-26**] weeks as outpatient
   - per neurosurg,  continue Keppra for total 7 days. Staples will come
   out after total 10 days
   - repeat head CTshowed residual acute hemorrhage. Per neurosurgery this
   is resolving and is not contributing to worsening apnea
   .
   # Sleep Apnea: BiBAP overnight and when napping
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: modified diet

Summary:

The patient is a 72-year-old man who underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) with a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 15%. He has a history of atrial fibrillation, systolic heart failure, and sleep apnea. He developed a subdural hematoma, which was evacuated, and has since been experiencing volume overload, hypotension, and respiratory distress. He was started on diuretics, but this led to overdiuresis, and he was given fluid boluses to correct the volume depletion. He is currently receiving continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) for oxygenation.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine level has increased to 2.1, indicating acute renal failure. This may be due to poor forward flow and overdiuresis.
2. Cardiomyopathy: The patient's LVEF is 15%, indicating restrictive cardiomyopathy. This may worsen his cardiac function and increase his risk of cardiac complications.
3. Subdural Hematoma: The patient's subdural hematoma has not fully resolved, and there is still residual acute hemorrhage. This may lead to further neurologic complications.
4. Sleep Apnea: The patient's sleep apnea may worsen his respiratory distress and increase his risk of cardiac complications.
5. Fluid Overload: The patient's fluid overload may worsen his cardiac function and increase his risk of cardiac complications.
6. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may worsen his cardiac function and increase his risk of cardiac complications.
7. Respiratory Distress: The patient's respiratory distress may worsen his cardiac function and increase his risk of cardiac complications.

Assessment and Plan:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust diuretics as needed.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac function and adjust medications as needed.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's neurologic status and adjust medications as needed.
4. Continue to provide CPAP for oxygenation and monitor the patient's respiratory status.
5. Consider central access to better measure the patient's fluid status.
6. Consider repeat echocardiogram to evaluate cardiac function.
7. Consider anticoagulation therapy to prevent further complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 72-year-old man who has undergone coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), has a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 15%, and has a biventricular pacemaker and ICD. He has also had a recent subdural hematoma evacuation and has developed volume overload, which has responded to initial diuresis. However, he has required a fluid bolus to correct the volume depletion and is now improved but still requiring CPAP for oxygenation due to underlying sleep apnea.

The patient's current medical conditions include:

1. Renal failure, acute (acute renal failure, ARF)
2. Cardiomyopathy, restrictive
3. Subdural hematoma (SDH)
4. Chronic kidney disease (CKD)
5. Coronary artery disease (CAD)
6. Systolic heart failure (CHF)
7. Atrial fibrillation
8. Sleep apnea

Potential medical complications that can arise from these conditions include:

1. Progressive kidney damage and need for dialysis
2. Worsening heart failure and decreased cardiac function
3. Increased risk of stroke and bleeding due to atrial fibrillation and subdural hematoma
4. Respiratory failure and need for mechanical ventilation
5. Infection and sepsis
6. Malnutrition and dehydration
7. Hypoglycemia and hyperglycemia
8. Increased risk of cardiac arrhythmias and sudden death

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

1. Holding diuretics and fluids and monitoring I/O
2. Continuing digoxin
3. Monitoring fluid and respiratory status
4. Considering central access for better measurement of fluid status
5. Considering repeat echo to evaluate cardiac function
6. Continuing metoprolol for rate control and uptitration as needed
7. No Coumadin for now, but considering it in three weeks
8. Attempting to touch base with neurosurgery regarding anticoagulation
9. Changing Plavix to aspirin if okay from neurosurgical perspective
10. Continuing simvastatin and metoprolol
11. Trending creatinine and holding further diuresis
12. Considering urine lytes if creatinine does not improve
13. Continuing insulin NPH + Humalog sliding scale at current dose
14. Continuing Keppra for total 7 days and staples will come out after total 10 days
15. Repeat head CT showed residual acute hemorrhage, which is resolving and not contributing to worsening apnea.

 ICD and

   extremities, he required a fluid bolus to correct the volume

   due to underlying sleep apnea.  Will continue to observe his mental
   status.
   72M h/o CAD s/p MI s/p CABG, systolic CHF (EF 15%) s/p ICD, atrial
   fibrillation s/p burr hole/evacuation for subdural hematoma with
   development volume overload clinically although no change on CXR.
   Volume overload likely [**12-25**] IV fluids during surgery in the setting of
   having nodal blocking [**Doctor Last Name **] and lasix held.
   .

   evidence by cold, clammy, mottled extremities and bump in creatinine.
   Responded well to fluid boluses as well as morphine for respiratory
   distress.
   - hold diuretics and fluids at this point and monitor I/O
   - start digoxin
   - continue to monitor fluid and respiratory status
   - consider central access if we feel we need a better measurement of
   his fluid status
   - consider repeat echo to evaluate cardiac function
   .

   - continue metoprolol for rate control, uptitrate as needed

   neurosurgical perspective)
   - continue simvastatin, metoprolol

   - repeat head CT today

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 72-year-old man who suffered a subdural hematoma and underwent evacuation. He has a history of coronary artery disease, heart failure, and atrial fibrillation. He was admitted to the ICU with acute renal failure, restrictive cardiomyopathy, and a biventricular pacemaker.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.1C, heart rate of 108 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 119/77 mmHg. He is receiving oxygen therapy and is being monitored for respiratory distress.

The patient's laboratory results show evidence of acute kidney injury, with a creatinine level of 2.1 mg/dL. His electrolyte levels are within normal limits, and his blood glucose level is controlled.

The patient's medical plan includes:

1. Continue to monitor his fluid and respiratory status, and consider central access if necessary.
2. Hold diuretics and fluids at this point and monitor I/O.
3. Start digoxin and continue to monitor its effect.
4. Consider repeat echo to evaluate cardiac function.
5. Continue metoprolol for rate control and uptitrate as needed.
6. No Coumadin for now, but consider it in 3 weeks after neurosurgical follow-up.
7. Attempt to touch base with neurosurgery regarding anticoagulation.
8. Continue simvastatin and metoprolol.
9. Trend creatinine and consider urine lytes if it does not improve.
10. Continue insulin NPH + Humalog sliding scale at current dose.
11. Continue Keppra for total 7 days, and staples will come out after 10 days.
12. Repeat head CT today.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Further deterioration of cardiac function, leading to heart failure or arrhythmias.
2. Progressive acute kidney injury, leading to chronic kidney disease.
3. Respiratory failure, requiring mechanical ventilation.
4. Infection, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia or central line-associated bloodstream infection.
5. Bleeding complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding or intracranial bleeding.
6. Electrolyte imbalances, such as hyperkalemia or hypokalemia.
7. Hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia, requiring adjustments to insulin therapy.
8. Neurological complications, such as seizures or increased intracranial pressure.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 72-year-old man who underwent CABG surgery, has a history of CAD, MI, and systolic CHF with an LVEF of 15%. He also has a biventricular pacemaker and ICD. He recently developed a subdural hematoma, which was evacuated via a burr hole.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Renal failure: He has acute renal failure with a creatinine level of 2.1 mg/dL, which is likely prerenal due to poor forward flow and overdiuresis. His urine output has decreased, and he requires fluid boluses to correct volume depletion.
* Cardiomyopathy: He has restrictive cardiomyopathy with an LVEF of 15%, which may be contributing to his poor forward flow and fluid overload.
* Subdural hematoma: His neurologic exam is stable, and he is being monitored for any changes. He will require repeat head CT scans and neurosurgical follow-up.
* Sleep apnea: He requires CPAP for oxygenation due to underlying sleep apnea.
* Other conditions: He has atrial fibrillation, which is being managed with metoprolol for rate control. He also has CAD s/p CABG and is on simvastatin and metoprolol. He has a history of DM and is being managed with insulin NPH and Humalog sliding scale.

Potential medical complications that can arise from these conditions include:

* Worsening of renal failure: If the patient's creatinine level continues to rise, he may require further interventions such as hemodialysis or peritoneal dialysis.
* Cardiac complications: His restrictive cardiomyopathy may worsen, leading to further fluid overload and decreased cardiac output. He may also develop arrhythmias or cardiac arrest.
* Neurological complications: He may develop further neurologic deficits or worsening of his subdural hematoma, which could lead to increased intracranial pressure and potential brain herniation.
* Respiratory complications: He may develop further respiratory distress or failure, which could lead to the need for mechanical ventilation.
* Infections: He is at risk for developing infections such as VAP, which could worsen his condition and increase his risk of mortality.
* Gastrointestinal complications: He may develop gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation, which could worsen his condition and increase his risk of mortality.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential complications, the plan of care should focus on managing his renal failure, cardiomyopathy, subdural hematoma, and sleep apnea. This may involve adjusting his medications, fluid management, and oxygenation. He should also be monitored closely for any changes in his condition and receive timely interventions to prevent complications.

   Assessment and Plan
 RENAL FAILURE, ACUTE (ACUTE RENAL FAILURE, ARF)
 CARDIOMYOPATHY, RESTRICTIVE
 SUBDURAL HEMORRHAGE (SDH)
   72 year old man s/p CABG, LVEF = 15%, biventricular pacemaker
 ICD and
   recent subdural hematoma evacuation developed volume overload which
   responded to initial diuresis, but due to hypotension and cool clammy
   extremities, he required a fluid bolus to correct the volume
   depletion.    He is now improved but requiring CPAP for oyxygenation
   due to underlying sleep apnea.  Will continue to observe his mental
   status.
   72M h/o CAD s/p MI s/p CABG, systolic CHF (EF 15%) s/p ICD, atrial
   fibrillation s/p burr hole/evacuation for subdural hematoma with
   development volume overload clinically although no change on CXR.
   Volume overload likely [**12-25**] IV fluids during surgery in the setting of
   having nodal blocking [**Doctor Last Name **] and lasix held.
   .
   # CHF/Fluid Overload: Likely overdiuresed yesterday morning, as
   evidence by cold, clammy, mottled extremities and bump in creatinine.
   Responded well to fluid boluses as well as morphine for respiratory
   distress.
   - hold diuretics and fluids at this point and monitor I/O
   - start digoxin
   - continue to monitor fluid and respiratory status
   - consider central access if we feel we need a better measurement of
   his fluid status
   - consider repeat echo to evaluate cardiac function
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation: Tachycardia likely contributing to patient
   symptoms, resulting in poor forward flow and further fluid overload.
   - continue metoprolol for rate control, uptitrate as needed
   - no Coumadin for now; can consider this in 3 weeks (after neurosurg
   f/u)
   - attempt to touch base with neurosurgery re: anticoagulation
   .
   # CORONARIES: CAD s/p CABG. Pt denies any chest pain at this time.
   - No apparent h/o PCI, so can change Plavix to aspirin (if okay from
   neurosurgical perspective)
   - continue simvastatin, metoprolol
   .
   #  Acute on Chronic renal failure: Cr 2.1 today, recent baseline of
   1.2. Likely prerenal from poor forward flow with superimposed
   overdiuresis.
   - continue to trend creatinine
   - holding further diuresis, as above
   - consider urine lytes if creatinine does not improve
   .
   # DM: Fasting hypoglycemia has resolved with decreased insulin dosing.
   - continue insulin NPH + Humalog sliding scale at current dose
   .
   # Subdural Hematoma s/p Burrhole/Evacuation: Neurologic exam stable.
   - neuro checks q4 hrs
   - appreciate neuro sx input
   - neurosurg f/u in [**12-26**] weeks as outpatient
   - per neurosurg,  continue Keppra for total 7 days. Staples will come
   out after total 10 days
   - repeat head CT today
   .
   # Sleep Apnea: BiBAP overnight and when napping
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:

   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:

   Code status:

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 72-year-old man who suffered a subdural hematoma, underwent evacuation, and is currently in the ICU. The patient has a history of coronary artery disease, previous myocardial infarction, and cardiac bypass surgery. He also has a pacemaker and implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD).

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

1. Persistent left subdural extra-axial collection with residual acute hemorrhage.
2. Renal failure, acute (acute renal failure, ARF), with a creatinine level of 2.1 mg/dL.
3. Cardiomyopathy, restrictive, with a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 15%.
4. Subdural hematoma s/p burr hole/evacuation, with neurologic exam stable.
5. Sleep apnea, requiring BiPAP overnight and when napping.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.1C (96.9F)
* Heart rate: 108 bpm (range 86-108 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 119/77 mmHg (range 84-121/89 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 36 breaths per minute (range 10-41 breaths per minute)
* SpO2: 95%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 11.7 x 10^9/L (range 4.5-11.0 x 10^9/L)
* Hematocrit: 44.4% (range 37-52%)
* Platelet count: 266 x 10^9/L (range 150-450 x 10^9/L)
* Creatinine: 2.1 mg/dL (range 0.5-1.2 mg/dL)
* Troponin-T: 0.04 ng/mL (range 0-0.1 ng/mL)

The patient's medications include:

* Aspirin (discontinued)
* Plavix (discontinued)
* Metoprolol (changed to p.o. and increased in dose)
* Digoxin (restarted)
* Omeprazole (changed to lansoprazole)
* Dilantin
* Heparin sodium (prophylaxis)
* Keppra (for 7 days)

Potential medical complications that may arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Worsening of renal failure, leading to further fluid overload and electrolyte imbalances.
2. Development of cardiac arrhythmias, such as atrial fibrillation, which may exacerbate the patient's cardiomyopathy.
3. Respiratory failure, particularly given the patient's sleep apnea and requirement for BiPAP.
4. Increased risk of bleeding, particularly in the setting of the patient's subdural hematoma and anticoagulation therapy.
5. Potential for further neurological deterioration, given the patient's history of subdural hematoma and current neurologic exam findings.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Continued monitoring of vital signs, laboratory results, and fluid status.
2. Holding diuretics and fluids, and monitoring I/O, to prevent further fluid overload.
3. Uptitration of metoprolol for rate control.
4. Restarting digoxin.
5. Continuing simvastatin and metoprolol.
6. Monitoring creatinine and trending urine lytes.
7. Holding further diuresis and considering urine lytes if creatinine does not improve.
8. Continuing insulin NPH + Humalog sliding scale at current dose.
9. Repeat head CT today.
10. Neuro checks q4 hrs and neurosurgical follow-up in 12-26 weeks.

 RENAL FAILURE, ACUTE (ACUTE RENAL FAILURE, ARF)
 CARDIOMYOPATHY, RESTRICTIVE
 SUBDURAL HEMORRHAGE (SDH)
   72 year old man s/p CABG, LVEF = 15%, biventricular pacemaker
 ICD and
   recent subdural hematoma evacuation developed volume overload which
   responded to initial diuresis, but due to hypotension and cool clammy
   extremities, he required a fluid bolus to correct the volume
   depletion.    He is now improved but requiring CPAP for oyxygenation
   due to underlying sleep apnea.  Will continue to observe his mental
   status.
   72M h/o CAD s/p MI s/p CABG, systolic CHF (EF 15%) s/p ICD, atrial
   fibrillation s/p burr hole/evacuation for subdural hematoma with
   development volume overload clinically although no change on CXR.
   Volume overload likely [**12-25**] IV fluids during surgery in the setting of
   having nodal blocking [**Doctor Last Name **] and lasix held.
   .
   # CHF/Fluid Overload: Likely overdiuresed yesterday morning, as
   evidence by cold, clammy, mottled extremities and bump in creatinine.
   Responded well to fluid boluses as well as morphine for respiratory
   distress.
   - hold diuretics and fluids at this point and monitor I/O
   - start digoxin
   - continue to monitor fluid and respiratory status
   - consider central access if we feel we need a better measurement of
   his fluid status
   - consider repeat echo to evaluate cardiac function
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation: Tachycardia likely contributing to patient
   symptoms, resulting in poor forward flow and further fluid overload.
   - continue metoprolol for rate control, uptitrate as needed
   - no Coumadin for now; can consider this in 3 weeks (after neurosurg
   f/u)
   - attempt to touch base with neurosurgery re: anticoagulation
   .
   # CORONARIES: CAD s/p CABG. Pt denies any chest pain at this time.
   - No apparent h/o PCI, so can change Plavix to aspirin (if okay from
   neurosurgical perspective)
   - continue simvastatin, metoprolol
   .
   #  Acute on Chronic renal failure: Cr 2.1 today, recent baseline of
   1.2. Likely prerenal from poor forward flow with superimposed
   overdiuresis.
   - continue to trend creatinine
   - holding further diuresis, as above
   - consider urine lytes if creatinine does not improve
   .
   # DM: Fasting hypoglycemia has resolved with decreased insulin dosing.
   - continue insulin NPH + Humalog sliding scale at current dose
   .
   # Subdural Hematoma s/p Burrhole/Evacuation: Neurologic exam stable.
   - neuro checks q4 hrs
   - appreciate neuro sx input
   - neurosurg f/u in [**12-26**] weeks as outpatient
   - per neurosurg,  continue Keppra for total 7 days. Staples will come
   out after total 10 days
   - repeat head CT today
   .
   # Sleep Apnea: BiBAP overnight and when napping
